author: Alex Michaelides
review: A gripping psychological thriller that keeps you guessing until the end. The story revolves around Alicia Berenson, a successful painter who shoots her husband and then never speaks again. Theo Faber, a criminal psychotherapist, becomes obsessed with uncovering the truth behind her silence and unravels secrets that blur the line between obsession and justice. Michaelides masterfully weaves suspense and intricate characters, making this a page-turner that delves into the complexities of the human mind.

author: Tara Westover
review: A powerful memoir about a woman who grows up in isolation and eventually escapes to seek education. Raised in a strict and abusive household in rural Idaho, Tara Westover never steps foot in a classroom until she is seventeen. The memoir takes readers through her incredible journey of self-education, where she battles against all odds to break free from her oppressive past and gain entry into elite universities. Her story is not only a testament to personal resilience but also a thought-provoking look at the transformative power of education and the importance of questioning what you've been taught.

author: Delia Owens
review: A mesmerizing tale of survival and love set in the marshlands of North Carolina. Kya Clark, the mysterious 'Marsh Girl,' lives in isolation in the wild, growing up in the marsh after being abandoned by her family. Owens paints a haunting picture of Kya's struggle for survival and her connection to nature, while weaving in a murder mystery that grips the local community. The story beautifully blends elements of romance, nature writing, and suspense, making it a profound meditation on loneliness, love, and resilience.

author: James Clear
review: An insightful guide on how small changes in habits can lead to remarkable results. James Clear breaks down the science of habit formation, showing how even the smallest changes in behavior, when done consistently, can have profound effects over time. The book provides actionable strategies for building good habits, breaking bad ones, and mastering the 'compound effect' of daily actions. Through real-life examples and scientific research, Clear offers readers practical tools to create lasting changes in their lives, from health to work, relationships, and beyond.

author: Margaret Atwood
review: A brilliant sequel to The Handmaid's Tale that expands the world of Gilead. Set more than fifteen years after the original novel, The Testaments follows three narratorsâ€”Aunt Lydia, one of the founding members of the regime, and two young women with drastically different experiences within Gilead. Atwood masterfully interweaves their stories to craft a gripping tale of rebellion, loyalty, and hope. The novel explores themes of power, control, and the resilience of the human spirit in the face of oppression, making it a thought-provoking and chilling follow-up to the iconic dystopian world.

author: Michelle Obama
review: A deeply personal memoir by the former First Lady of the United States. In Becoming, Michelle Obama reflects on her life experiences, from her childhood on the South Side of Chicago to her time spent in the White House. The memoir is an inspiring account of a woman who has always strived to 'become' her best self, both personally and professionally. Through candid storytelling, she shares her struggles with race, gender, and identity, offering insight into the world of politics, public life, and her journey to becoming a role model for women across the globe.
